reviews.review_text: This is a great game for JRPG fans. This is NOT good for casual gamers. If you're already familiar with the 'Tales of' series, you know exactly what you're getting into. For those of you who only know Tales of Symphonia, this game is very similar, with a very improved combat system, and a bit shorter. If you liked other entries in the series, you'll probably enjoy this one as well. It's a little bit more complicated than the others, though. If you like JRPGs and aren't familiar with Tales games, this is a good place to start.   Fun: 8.5/10   Gameplay: 9/10   Graphics: 10/10   Audio: 10/10   Replay Value:  There's a New Game+ option with extra difficulty modes and other options that you can change from one playthrough to another, so if you're a completionist, you might want to replay up to 3 or even 5 times. There's also a DLC chapter focusing on a minor character.  10/10    Let's get this out of the way first: Tales of Zestiria is a JRPG, but it does not have turn-based combat and is not a grindy game. In fact, your characters' levels matter much less than what equipment they use and how you control them in the real-time battles, both of which are based on some systems that are difficult to understand at first and brushed a lot of people the wrong way (see below for an overview). The lack of a need to grind, the presence of a good Quick Travel system and the lack of needlessly big, empty regions (except for one) mean that the game flows very well, and except for a single bit near the end which doesn't even take 15 minutes total to clear, it never feels like battles and simple puzzles are being tossed at you just to increase play time, as it often does with so many other games of the genre.  The game's localization was very well-done. One particular character has a thing for puns and 'dad jokes', which are very hard to localize because often they can't be translated and you have to come up with a new one along the same lines. The English versions of those might be one of my favorite parts of the game. The English voice acting is also very good for the most part. I don't know Japanese, so I can't compare, but the English language audio and text are on point.  The story is nothing exceptional, but good enough and well-told. The soundtrack is really good.The game world is immersive, there are interesting NPCs and sidequests, and I had fun just going out to explore places instead of actually following the story on several occasions. A big part of the game are the correlated Skills and Fusion systems, which I enjoyed playing around with, but which also frustrated many people. I'll get into those below.  There's an unofficial patch that allows the game to run at 60fps if you care about that sort of thing.   SPECIFICS  As I mentioned, character levels aren't as important in Tales of Zestiria as they are in the average JRPG. It's possible to take down an enemy twice your level or to be defeated by an enemy half your level, all depending on how you fight and on what equipment you have. Equipment stat boosts are much larger than your stat growth when you level up, but even more important than that are the Skills that your equipment comes with. Two otherwise identical weapons that happened to drop with different Skills on them can be significantly different from each other, depending on what other equipment you're wearing. In the beginning of the game, Skills aren't that important, but as the game progresses, they become more and more relevant. Certain bosses simply can't be beaten if you don't have the right Skills equipped.    THE BATTLE SYSTEM  When you encounter an enemy, a wide circular area will be closed around you to form the field of battle. You can move around freely,dodge, block, attack and defend in real time, and issue generic commands to the party members you're not controlling directly (spread out, focus on the same enemy, focus on attacking, focus on defense). By pausing the battle, you can enter a menu and order any non-controlled character to use a specific 'arte' (the game's name for attacks, special moves and magic). You can also change which character you control mid-battle. There are five elements (Void/Non-Elemental, Fire, Earth, Water and Wind) to which enemies can be weak, neutral or resistant. In addition, each element is associated to a status ailment (e.g. Water to Poison) and a character stat (e.g. Void to Attack). Every single arte you use will have one or more elements, and every arte of a given element has the potential to cause the respective element's status ailment or give you a buff to the corresponding stat when used. Enemies also have Types (e.g. Flying, Armored, Beast) against which certain attacks are strong. An attack that's strong against an enemy type will deal bonus damage even if that enemy is strong against the attack's element. There are three numbers to keep an eye on during battle: your HP, your SC (Spirit Chain) and your BG (Blast Gauge). BG is used for certain especially powerful artes and for a unique mechanic called Armatization. SC is what you use for actually fighting. Your maximum SC is always 100 and everything you do in battle except running and blocking costs some SC. SC recovers over time during the battle, but if you attack too quickly or too often, you'll run out and have to wait. The lower your SC goes, the slower it recovers.   SKILLS  Each character has five different equipment slots, and each piece of equipment has four Skill slots. There are a total of 50 different Skills that can give you anything from stat boosts to increased HP recovery, protection against an element or status ailment, added damage against certain enemies, etc. These Skills are organized into a 5x10 grid where each of the 5 lines corresponds to an element and each of the 10 collumns corresponds to a theme (e.g. the first collumn is stat boosts, the 9th collumn is increased damage of the respective types). Every Skill from currently equipped gear will be active on that character's Skill Chart.  Skills can be combined for added bonus effects, which can be even more dramatic than the basic Skills themselves (such as reflecting 30% of all damage of a particular element, having an extra Blast Gauge or gaining a 20% Max HP increase). The Bonus Skills depend on where skills are on the 5x10 Skills chart. There are three types of Bonus Skills: Stack (multiple copies of the same Skill), E-Union (two or more adjacent skills in the same horizontal line) and G-Union (all five Skills on the same collumn). Equipping two of the same skill, for instance, reduces the time you spend staggered by 6%. If you have multiple stacks of two, their effects add up - a stack of stacks, if you will. This means you can become completely immune to certain status ailments by equipping the right skills.   FUSION  Every piece of equipment you get will have at least one skill and up to four. In weapon shops, it's possible to fuse two pieces of equipment and combine their skills, while also improving the equipment's stats with each fusion. Slots that have the same skill in both fused weapons, or any skill in one weapon and a blank slot in the other will keep that same skill in the resulting fused weapon. Slots that are empty in both weapons will continue empty. Slots that have different skills in each weapon will end up with a third skill that is different from both. Because of this mechanism, through fusion you can create equipments with the Skill set you want, to match your play style or enable a specific strategy against a particular foe.   CONCLUSION  If the above description of game mechanics didn't scare you, and you enjoy JRPGs, you'll probably enjoy Tales of Zestiria. If not, then you've probably stopped reading already anyway, but don't buy the game. That is all.

At nearly 12 hours into the game I have to wonder: am I playing the same game as everyone else?  The story thus far is miserable. 12 hours of play and I couldn't describe most characters to you. What do they want? What drives them? In Tales of Vesperia, within minutes of meeting of meeting the protagonist you understood his motivation and got to watch him and his friends grow over the next 40-odd hours. In Zestiria, I still couldn't tell you why the protagonist, Sorey, is even on his adventure. He seems to have shrugged his shoulders and said, 'Meh, let's save the world.' He's basically the character equivalent of plain, dry toast: inoffensive and uninteresting.   If characterization is paper thin, the plot is almost see-through. Most villains vanish, defeated, within minutes of meeting them. Schemers will tell you their entire plan at the drop of a hat. Whatever amorphous Big Bad lurks behind the scenes hasn't made so much as a single appearance. The party seems to bounce from area to area without any lead-in or world-building of any kind. I don't care about where we are or what we're doing because the game hasn't given me a reason to.  Yes, the combat system is messy, needlessly complicated, and arcane. And yes, the combat camera just loves to point at walls or the enemy's ankles. Honestly, I could live with that.  But I can't live with the fact that, after half a DAY of play, I don't care about these characters or this world.

Tales of Zestiria is almost passable if you enjoy Tales games. Awful if you just like RPGs. I am usually a fan of Tales games however Zestiria leaves much to be desired. It's actually the first in the series that I could not bring myself to complete.   The plot is cliche, none of the twists that you would expect out a Tales game were there at all. There are no betrayals, no surprises, no complex moral issues; and how could there be? Every single one of the characters is introduced as a flat anime cliche, and remains a flat anime cliche. The only interesting protagonist is unfortunately a temporary character.(mainly playable in paid DLC no less). The villains are equally as bad, there are less than half a dozen named villains I could even remember. The setting is rather bland and the world's lore works off corny premises that leave a lot to be desired.   The gameplay is where the game becomes truly cringeworthy. If you insist on playing this game, please play with a friend. (3 friends would be ideal, but for some reason this entry in the series only supports two players). The AI does not recognize the mechanics of the rock-paper-scissors system of gameplay, making it sometimes easier to simply set them to block and do nothing. The battle system has gotten rid of the aerial combat Tales of Xillia, and combat is now ground based.  Progression is also non-linear. Leveling up is essentially useless, skills and stats are strictly tied to equipment. This allows you to customize your characters strengths as you see fit, however it ends up taking a long time to assess whether a piece of equipment is an upgrade or if your shiny new sword will actually make you weaker. This ends up creating a long grind for the correct skills, and skill combos to maximize the strength of your characters.   Graphically this game is only a small improvement over the PS3 games. Even though Some settings are larger and more detailed than in past games. The game runs at 30fps, and is fairly optimized, but it seemed enemies on the map were sometimes rendered at an awkwardly lower rate for some reason.   Overall Tales of Zestiria takes far more steps back than it takes forward. Of the Tales Games I have played it has by far been my least favorite, as such I wouldn't recommend it to anyone but the most die hard Tales Fans.

Tales of Zestiria is Namco Bandai's first release of a Tales game on PC and the port is pretty solid. There's only a little bit of stuttering with maxed out settings. All-in-all it's a very good first port of a Tales series to PC. It follows the Tales formula of innocent youth facing a harsh world that was popularised in Tales of Symphonia and overcoming adversity with the power of friendship (though not Tales of Graces f 'FRIENDSHIP'). The characters are written very well and feel like they could be real people facing the struggles within the game.  Pros:   Constant frame rate in battle. There have been no dropped frames inside battles.   There is different AI patterns based off of difficulty. I noticed this when I was fighting a certain boss earlier in the game. His attack patterns were more stragetic in trying to stagger me instead of just trying to attack through my combos.   Humorous dialogue. A lot of the skits have been localised fairly well and feel like they keep the original tone.   Cons:   30 FPS lock. Before this review is obliterated by the dislike button hear me out. There's noticeable input lag when trying to do big combos during the game. There are times where a combo should have been fired off but it winds up not happening because the input was received on the wrong frame. It is jarring to have this happen repeatedly in a fight where you need to be able to stun-lock/combo-lock your opponent. I really do hope that Tales of Symphonia on PC is not just a direct port of the PS3 version which is similarly locked at 30 FPS.   Level pacing. This may just be me playing on Moderate/Hard on my first playthrough but there is a crushing level spike with every new area. Where most of the level spike can be off-put by mastering the dodge system and having a lot of Battle Skills active, the level spikes make it feel like grinding is the answer to a lot of the progression problems.

So, Tales of Zestiria. First of all, I'll inform you that I'm a bit of a “Tales of” fan, but with them being scattered across various consoles, I've played only 3 of them before Zestiria: Symphonia, Abyss and Vesperia. Given the background, I'll make some comparisons, but I'll try to stick to the game to itself.  I'll start right away with my overall impression, then if you'll like you can read the details behind my opinion. Tales of Zestiria it's an okay game: it's fun, it has interesting characters, the music is awesome, the battle system is quick paced. However, it's a bit of roller-coaster, with highs and lows, hits and misses; some aspects of the game are too simple, while other are too complicate. I'll stick on a 7,5/10 as a numeric value. If you're a “Tales of” fan, prepare for many changes; if you never played a “Tales of” game, this is a really nice JRPG, that needs some work on some things. In both cases, it will be a good experience!  So, why 7,5? Let's find out  Zestiria is a JRPG, so it's the usual mix of exploration, puzzles and battles, which are in real time: you command directly one of the characters in the party, while the others are guided by the CPU, that follows a series of guidelines customizable by the player. It's basically an action game, quick paced, fast, fun and enjoyable. However, you can still coordinate the attacks of the whole party, giving specific commands if you want to take on the battles with a more strategic approach.  Now, the system has really changed from the previous “Tales of” games: you don't have a mana bar, but rather an action bar, that depletes when you attack or when you dodge, but it refills automatically if you defend or simply stand still. You don't have 'basic attacks' as in the other “Tales of” games, but rather different techniques (Artes) that you can use. Point is, the close combat Artes common to all the characters (the Martial Artes) are 'linear': you can do four attack in a combo before being forced to reset it, but the possibilities are very limited. At the first attack, you'll have to pick one of two specific Martial Artes, at the second one one of four specific Martial Artes and so on; at the second attack you can't pick a Martial Arte that triggers only at the fourth move. And it's a bit of a pain, since every enemy has weakness related to specific attacks. There are ways to break their resistance of course, you are playing with four characters after all so one of them will be able to strike hard the enemy when you can't. But aside from that, the combos you'll be able to create are impersonal and limited: back in Vesperia, it was GORGEUS to see the characters fighting... I made a 300+ hit combo in there! That was SO fun! Zestiria, however, becomes too repetitive too quickly. Of course, you have other types of melee attacks (the Occult Artes) and the classic long range magic attacks (the Seraphic Artes), so there are still possibilities, but still... This battle system feels like a bit of step backwards in order to make new things. They also added lots of battle rules and specific actions that are simply too many: it's nice to improve a fighting system by making it deeper, but I think they got too far. They also added a range of 50 skills bound to your equipments: from them, it comes most of the fighting power your characters will be able to acquire; you'll also be able to fuse equipments to either power up existing skills or making new ones. But even here, it's a bit too much: as I said, 50 skills. You really need a guide to understand how to get the desired result.  In short, they took many risks, some paid off, some didn't. It's still enjoyable, but it feels like they added too much to renovate the system.  The characters are enjoyable; we've seen better in the “Tales of” history, but we've seen worse. Tales of Zestiria brings Bandai Namco's latest entry in its long line of fast-paced JRPGs to Western audiences, and notably for the first time to PC via Steam. It sports a cheery anime style and offers a meaty ability system for players to delve into, as JRPGs tend to do, capped off with the series' well-known (and trademarked) action-based combat.  The story follows a young man named Sorey, who has been raised away from humanity and early on in the story discovers he is their saviour - their 'Shepherd'. Along the way he meets entities representing the various natural elements and that he is able to fuse with ('armatize') in combat.  Combat is the defining feature of any Tales game, and Zestiria makes a few tweaks to the system such as battles no longer taking place in a separate arena. If there's a rock to your left when you encounter an enemy on the map, it'll be there during battle.  The rest of the combat system remains fairly intact - for the uninitiated, that includes chaining combos, a mix of physical and magical abilities, and an elemental strengths and weakness rock-paper-scissors system.  The fusion ability that Sorey unlocks early in the game is incredibly fun and powerful, but there are also genuine tactical reasons to not fuse. It's not like a Final Fantasy-style limit break that you just want to fire off as soon as it's ready, though doing so is rarely a truly terrible idea.  What really lets Zestiria down, though, is its equipment system. Each piece of equipment can come with up to four skills on it which represent a tile on a grid. Match the tiles either horizontally or vertically to enable bonus skills, and fuse matching pieces of gear together to create stronger gear with the skills you want... or in theory, that's how it works.  In practice, it actually restricts you - you make your way to the bottom of a dungeon, kill the boss and he drops an awesome weapon, but you can't use it because it doesn't have the right skills, breaking your horizontal or vertical lines, and equipping it is a net stat loss. It's a really unsatisfying feeling.  Zestiria sits in an odd spot within the market. For fans of the series, and JRPGs in general, it offers little in the way of surprise, and while enjoyable does come off a little trite. Gamers of this persuasion can probably pick up Zestiria with little fear of a poor experience, but shouldn't expect to be completely blown away.  Newcomers, however, are thrown head-first into the game's convoluted equipment and fusion systems. The game does offer the option to (further) simplify combat, but its true intention is to remove any necessity to correctly upgrade your equipment.  Outside this, enjoyment will come down to the individual's tolerance for Zestiria's anime influence in its appearance and in its story. If you're more of a cringer than a cheerer, then you may not want to follow this Shepherd.

I enjoyed this game far, far more than I expected I would - I thought I would skip this entry as I thought the trailer betrayed lower production values than tales of Xillia, and I wasnt sold on the character designs. Regarding the latter, I still dislike Mikleo's clothes and Soreys stupid ear feathers, but after our 70 hours together I love them far too much to care. I loved them enough after 2.   However, The game does seem have Lower Production values than Xillia. The Field environments are far better spatially designs than the blobs of land seen in Xillia, but in parts are very, for want of a better word, polygony. The town and dungeon areas dont seem as well designed as Xillia but they arent quite so polygony. Possibly because most of the dungeons are ruins which could be made from repeatable rectilinear assets which would reduce the work needed.   The battle system is a bit of a departure from previous games. The battle system has been gradually become more are more 3 dimensional in each installment, and using the battle ability 'Free and Free' completly removes the 2d axis you traditionally fight on. I didnt. The ability to fuse with the different seraphim characters in your Party is good to really mix up the playstyle, whether it's for defensive reasons, in order the withstand a bosses blows, or just for when you get surrounded by enemies weak to water and want to maelstrom them into oblivion. The camera is not great. It is what it is.   One thing that has come under fire is the abilities on a grid system. It is quite complicated. There are 50 abilities which all occupy a grid. Line up 2 or more horizontally you will get different elemental bonuses, or of you get all 5 in a collumn vertically you get a stat boost. For example for the first collumn grants you 10% boost on all stats. However I was fearful of losing this bonus after I had gotten it and as as a result by characters were wearing 1st and 2nd tier equipment far too late in the game for them to be doing so. I later opted for equiping all the strongest equipments for their various strengths and making small consessions for certain abilities to make up for a characters weaknesses or provide abilities beneficial for certain bosses. For example I equipped Sorey with 3 peices of equipment with the Lindwer ability, providing 45% more damage against dragons (15 each), and the bonus for stacking 3 was adding an extra unit to my blast gauge (blast gauge being expended for fusing and special attacks).  The Strong point in this game in the characters. They are so likeable. I didnt think anyone would replace Jude Mathis of Tales of Xillia at the top of my list of most likeble Tales Protagonists but Sorey may have done just that. Theres lots of skits that expand on the characters, and even the enemy information is full little tidbits of Lailahs puns, Edna's snark and insults directed at Mikleo, and Sorey being so enamored with the little gun carts the goblins ride that he wished to be the first Goblin Shepherd (all the while being lightly chastised by Mikleo). Theres something quite refreshing about opening the enemy info mid boss and have rose making a Joke. Theres also a fair amount of fun in the item descriptions as well (Soreys not allowed to touch Mikleos hair, not since the incident) and its these little touches that really make Tales of Zestiria.   Theres also a good soundtrack, a few pieces being outstanding, an overall improvement on previous games in the series.   If the question comes down to whether its better than Tales of Xillia then the answer is no, but that comparing an excellent JRPG with a very good one. If you have a PS3 play Xillia first. If you dont this is still worth your time and money.  I only meant to write a short few words to show support. Whoops.  And Meebo is my Precious Angel.

Tales of Zestiria is the first attempt at a full 3D combat system by the Tales series and it largely falls flat. The story is what you expect in a typical series, but there\'s numerous problems with the game and you\'d think that a company that has been making these types of RPGs for nearly 20 years would be learning from their mistakes. First and foremost are the controls. They haven\'t been adopted to fit the 3D style. Holding down now often means holding back, and your character runs backwards when you try to use down + attack or down + arte. Another problem with the game is that you only have 2 human characters to use at a time. One human character can only be partnered up with one of the Seraphs, spirit like beings that only some people can see. The result is that even though you have four characters in your party, you can only use two. I also hope you don't get too attached to the heroine of the game because she gets replaced halfway through.  A serious issue I had with the game is the fact that Lailah is somehow bound to not speak about the past. The emphasis of learning your own answer through a journey is important, but the fact that she withholds crucial information throughout the game makes me feel like everyone is an idiot.  Another problem with the game is that the enemies have huge amounts of super armor and invincibility frames. Super armor is when the enemy breaks your combo and become immune to stun and knockbacks for a period of time. Invincibility is when they are immune to all damage while they are performing their attack. This occurs far too frequently in the game and many enemies activate it after a fixed number of hits, automatically ending your combo, even if they are airborne at the moment. Ironically, many of your character\'s powered up transformations hit very rapidly and very quickly, allowing you to make high hit combos. The problem is that this automatically triggers the enemy\'s auto response that makes them invincibile, largely making this feature useless.  There are some massive changes in this game compared to the other ones. Levels mean nothing in this game as it only gives you additional HP and the ability to equip more Skills (you can get more of those points from finding stupid monuments in the game than leveling up though). Stats are acquired from new equipment and killing bosses, not from leveling up. They also changed Grades and Skills to be unlocked by acquiring achievements. There are hints as to what you need to do to unlock them, but it quickly becomes something tedious. For the first time there is also no dedicated healer. Instead, everyone has a bunch of small heals, nothing that is meant for the entire party. Compared to the previous installments of Tales of Xillia and Tales of Xillia 2, this game has a worse story and worse gameplay.  The only good thing about buying this game was that I received Tales of Symphonia for free because I pre-ordered a terrible game. Hopefully Tales of Bestiria will improve on the combat and the story.

I know... that's really a change up!  The characters: I never really liked the lead in Tales games, they are mostly boring and pretty uninteresting, sometimes even unlikeable (I'm looking at you Luke) - Lloyd being the exception - but I don't mind Sorey to be honest. Graphic and sound stuff: Graphics are fine, but you can see, that this game was developed for the PS3, the music is in parts really damn good and never bad.  Gameplay: The gameplay/battles feel definetely a bit dumbed down from previous entries. It is a jRPG , it is a Tales game.  Speaking as someone who had played almost every single Tales game out there from Phantasia ,Abyss, Rebirth , Destiny , Destiny 2 , Destiny remake ,Symphonia , Graces F , Legendia ...etc ( beside the Tales of dungeons and spin-offs ) ,it is hard for me to recommend this game to anyone , even to diehard Tales fans.  Zestiria does has a likable Artstyle and game graphics, dated but likable .especially if you are the sort who enjoy watching Anime and playing RPG ,which is why you are checking this game out .  The character dubs are decent and since the game came with dual languages on Steam, for those who like watching their Jap-dubbed anime with English subs , this should be familiar.  Comparing to the Playstation 3 version , the graphics in the game have also received a slight upgrades and the characters looks a lot sharper , the game environment and background is 'cleaner ' . It is however , still primarily a Playstation 3 game so don't expect anything you will see from the triple AAA games in 2015. One of the major complains from the fans is the game is still locked in its good old-fashion 30 Frame rate . It shouldn't be too notice-able unless you are a graphic and performance police , but even by the general standard in 2015 , a 60 fps solid port will make your fans much happier , Namco Bandai.  Additionally , there is a fan-made mod that seems to enable 60 fps but I have had occassional game crashes with that , so I wouldn't recommend installing it ( at least at the time of writing this review )  And what makes this Tales game special ? This is apparently the Tales team first effort go Open-world with Tales game , the world map are pretty large to explore and traveling from town to towns may take a while , with the occasionally interesting discovery . Despite of having a larger world map , most of the location are still somewhat boring and bland to look at .  The combat system itself is pretty fun , your typical Tales - smash N smash . Easy to play , hard to master . And great thing is this time you get to quick-switch among all your active party members in the combat , nobody is left behind.   So why wouldn't I recommend the game ?  Because the Game Story is a complete mess. And that is actually an understatement .  Not only the writing is a disaster , the presentation is boring , the game setting uninspiring , game characters also lack depth , almost making less sense than your local music channel. To be fair , the Tales team did attempt to grow out of the jRPG stereotypes and try new things . While the open world seamless combat transition works pretty well here , Bandai Namco had hired a proper writer , because many of the game aspects are not only getting old but becoming worse.   It's a jRPG , many may argue the recent jRPGs don't really has good story , but this one has probably one of the worst out there.   TL;DR : good port from the ps4 version , with pretty fun combat at first which eventually gets too complicated , grinding for high end equipment takes years , story doesn't make senses , plots a mess .

The short version:   Why to buy: It's a Tales of... game on PC. If you're a fan that alone is a good reason to support the release. It’s also a pretty solid port.  Feels like it is probably the best available version of the game -- my only regret is that I don't have a physical case to accompany the others in my collection. Has both Japanese and English options for audio!   Why to skip: Maybe not the best in the series.  The overall design is good but the battles are pretty meh due to how they are balanced. Way too much gear optimization/crafting for my tastes.   The nitty-gritty:   So, this could be overly negative in how it is presented. By the time I had reached the end of a 40 hour playthrough I was pretty tired of the mechanics and level design. However, it still takes strides forward that I appreciate, it’s just that the implementation probably could have been better.   At the start, everything was great.. The areas were large and beautifully presented. The battles seemed more or less on par with any other Tales game to date and everything was peachy. None of the characters outright seemed to be overly annoying or just plain oddly presented (thanks Graces F). The presentation or triggering for skits was a one of my favorite improvements - they now occur predictably at save points and Inns, making it relatively easy to know then to expect them. It takes the stress out of those ‘Oh crap did I just miss one’ moments that sometimes occur in other Tales games.   However, as my playtime increased, I noticed that the dungeons stopped presenting new twists. . Admittedly this is all a part of the fact that there are quite a few extra dungeons thrown in for good measure, but the overall quality seems to dip after a certain point. I should have just skipped what was unnecessary but a completionist bent made that difficult.    The combat system did not help with this either. The overall approach to combat feels like it’s been simplified to the point of being trivial. Magic does not have any actual cost - resulting in no items related to MP consumption even existing at all. Even in the heat of battle it only takes a moment of blocking in order to recharge to full, so there is no point to being stingy on the heaviest hitting moves you have.    This resulted in the next problem, that in order to avoid spending time grinding needlessly you I spent most of the later part of the game just running from Point A to Point B, dodging monsters the best I could through lengthy, repetitive environments. My enthusiasm then fizzed out, resulting in a need to just finish the game to be done with it. The overworld areas are fairly nice and all, but it seems like it could have benefited from a more condensed approach to the design, or less backtracking. This is somewhat managed by the teleportation mechanics but they tend to be finicky on how they function and will often bar you from using spots near to your objective (for scripting/trigger purposes I assume). Perhaps at some point they will get to a system that clicks better, but I’d almost rather they just go back to overworld maps at this point, as they tended to help create a better sense of scope and vastness to the world.   That all being said, I still don’t regret the purchase. It still holds a lot of the Tales characteristic charm and warmth via character interaction and development. They also spent a considerable amount of time investing in the villain's backstory - more than I think any other Tales games has before. While it still has an echo of the whole ‘Just cause,’ reasoning for ending the world, there is much more explanation into the ‘why’ of the villain's motives. Tropes still ensue in excess, it still feels far more well-rounded than I would normally expect.   Also, while I am bothered by many of the finer aspects of combat there are also still plenty of moments in which the system clicks and just feels good. It probably just suffers a bit from the scope of the game, resulting in the same problem I normally have with many open-world games - tons of content is great, but it can also be a pain when you have certain expectations regarding how extensive you want to be in searching every nook and cranny. I would recommend approaching Zestria as either taking your sweet time throughout the playthrough, or by letting yourself skip side-quests to avoid exhaustion.

To preface my review, I've been playing this game for almost 7 hours now and I have to say that out of what I've played of this game so far, this is one of my favorites in the series. The voice actors are very good and I won't fault them, but Tales of Zestiria has changed the regular system from the old series favorite of having you page through dialogue bubbles, into making all story relevant things into cutscenes. Now while you can still progress through the text at your own speed by clicking the confirm button, I find that with the english voice acting there is an abudance of awkward spacing between lines that aren't in the japaense voice acting. As I said though, you can always fast forward through dialogue, so it's purely personal preference.  This game was ported in my opinion, BEAUTIFULLY, I have the game running on low settings due to some screen tearing at times, but it hardly takes away from the beauty of the game and the framerate in my personal opinion is fantastic.  The battle system has been enhanced wonderfully with a now near seamless transition from running around into battling in the very same area that you stopped in, say on the world map you get attacked by an enemy on a bridge, well then you're fighting right where you're standing with no break away from the map. Even with my computer occassionally chugging due to the large map on the world map, the game runs completely fine even with you battling in the same area and I've only seen lag from some of the flashier artes that your team uses.  Each of the characters are very endearing in my opinion, I personally had a distaste for Estele in Tales of Vesperia, but the main female lead for this game is fantastic and is very endearing to me as I can tell, unlike Estele, that she truly cares for other people and is willing to go out of her way for others. I thought at first that I would dislike the main character, Sorey, but he proved himself to be a fantastic character with a pretty good personality that stays happy go lucky even in some of the darker parts of the game.  I still have far to go in the game, but so far this game has proven itself to me to be a very enticing entry in the series with certain dialogue options that I'm still curious as to how they might affect things later on in the game. If you're a big fan of the Tales of series, I can personally recommend this one.

Another wonderful addition to the Tales of Series, to those who have not before played any of them, worry not!   Each Tales of game is unique and they have nothing to do with eachother (Excluding Tales of Xillia 1 and 2)   I have had zero errors with the game, but I do run it mostly using Steamlink and with a Steamcontroller on windows 10, so I couldn't possibly say if any other OS or keyboard/mouse might have some trouble.

Gameplay - Battle System (6/10)     Heavily inspired by Tales of Graces' battle system except it is much more restrictive (much more restrictive compared to every Tales game, that was released after Vesperia) since everything is based on 4 hit combos whereas in, for example in Graces and Xillia you could chain combos as long as you had the AC/CC to do so.     The battle system heavily relies on exploiting the battle system's main point, Armatize.     Seraphim characters automatically switch out when they are incapitated in battle if they are partnered with a character you are not controlling and you cannot switch them back for a while, meaning you can't throw life bottles on them when that happens which is really annoying. Additionally some conditions will cause automatic Armatize whether you like it or not.    Glaringly obvious and consistent camera issues in battle throughout the entire game.    Removing shortcut keys (right analog stick on previous Tales games) for setting artes/ally artes is a straight downgrade from previous games, even Phantasia GBA had this.    Seraphim characters' arte pools had to suffer to make Armatize better. 7 offensive spells per Seraphim really?    No primary healer character, each Seraphim has 2 spells that are hybrid healing+buffing spells with EXTREMELY LONG cast times when you aren't using them at the end of the 4 hit combo. Meanwhile Armatize healing spells cost BG but have nearly instanaeous cast time and are very potent, again Seraphims had to suffer due to this battle system.    For certain battles where the boss has a high resistance to a certain element the Seraphim of that element is pretty much worthless. Lailah and Mikleo have a much heavier focus in their respective element compared to the other two Seraphim.    Forced party members. Firstly you must have two human characters in your party at all times (unless the other human who isn't Sorey has temporarily left the group) and Seraphim characters must pair up with each human. If the only human in your party is Sorey you are only allowed to bring 1 Seraphim with you in battle (2-man party) despite the entire Seraphim group being with you. Secondly almost every single story boss battle forces the battle to start with Mikleo and Lailah despite your initial party setup being otherwise, like... why the ♥♥♥♥.    A lot of battles will begin in narrow corridors making it very difficult to move around.    Gameplay - Outside of battle (5/10)     The equipment-skill system is unnecessarily complicated and simply impractical. The skills that come with equipment are very random and you will not be able to get the skill alignments you want unless you really min-max in the end game where it doesn't really matter anymore.    Titles in this game give large benefits when mastered but there are extremely few, part of the fun of previous Tales games was collecting titles...    Extremely little weapon variety and they don't even have menu artwork for them. Even the apple gels don't have artwork.    Fields are extremely large for...no reason at all. There's very few treasure chests in the corners of the map too. Yeah OK they look nice but hills of grass and trees gets boring after a while.    Story (7/10)     The story is a very straightforward collect x powers plot with very little twist or turns in it. Story progression is very linear (the map allows you to travel to different areas but the areas you aren't supposed to go to at whatever point of the story you're at are blocked off or filled with Malevalonce making battles pretty much impossible to win so you can't go that way either).    The story does a good job exploring what's right and what's wrong, what's black and white and staying in the grey zone most of the time.    World/story/sidequest issues either resolve themselves the moment they emerge, the party are simply not allowed to resolve the issue (because the plot point is that the Shepard cannot get involved with human issues...), or they just flat out ignore it and hope for the best (  Alisha gets held hostage at one point, the party initially act according to the villain's demands but then they just hope she makes it out OK after they finish their business without checking her status at all LOL?  )    Characters (8/10)   One thing Zestiria does well is the character interactions during cutscenes. Even during certain serious cutscene Lailah tries to crack a pun to ease the tension or Edna makes sarcastic remarks which is quite different from usual Tales games where cutscenes are mostly only serious or humourous. The most boring/unlikable characters in this game are nowhere near as unlikable as characters such as Asbel in Graces.     Sorey: Not a bad character but he's just very bland.    Mikleo: A bit less naive than Sorey but still very boring. Doesn't help that he has some character overlap with Sorey too (both ruin freaks, both the youngest physically+mentally in the party, both less knowledgable about the world than everyone else in the party)    Sorey + Mikleo honestly just feel like one character instead of two.    Lailah: Pretty funny character with puns and random wacky moments. She also has a lot of backstory to cover throughout Sorey's journey. It's pretty funny when other characters beat her at coming up with puns for the current situation too lol.    Edna: Also a funny character with how she continuously trolls the more suspectible or naive characters in the party. She also has a very sarcastic way of speaking pretty much 24/7.    Rose: Her purpose is mainly to do what Sorey can't.   Such as murdering people  . She's a pretty down to earth character who gets the job done.    Alisha: Likeable character with a strong sense of justice and someone who is willing to work for that justice. Her history nerdy interactions with Sorey are quite nice to see too.   Too bad she leaves the party permanently early on      Dezel: Pretty boring character, either doesn't speak much or the game tries to subtly show that he is looking out for the party but most of the time he's quite distant with the party and doesn't interact much at all.       Zaveid: Really makes the character interactions and skits much more humourous.       There aren't as many skits as previous titles and they aren't nearly as funny as Graces, Xillia 2's. Also many skits require you to sleep at an inn multiple times to view which is annoying.    Graphics (7/10)     Landscapes and dungeons are gorgeous to look at.    Character models use very vibrant colours compared to the previous Tales games which is a nice touch.    Towns are extremely boring to look at in this game, they are all some variation of a castle town besides a couple. None of the towns stand out, compare this to Xillia's Fenmont or Graces' desert or military snow towns.    A few tilesets recycled from Xillia, the forests and caves.    Arte visuals are a lot less flashy than previous Tales games, Graces included and that was a Wii game. I'm guessing they did this to improve performance after the past few games had FPS issues with heavy arte spam.    Music (10/10)   The music in this game is amazing holy ♥♥♥♥. Especially the trial temple dungeons and dragon fights.  The water temple was annoying as ♥♥♥♥ but the music made the annoyance so pleasant, that's how amazing the music is.    Thank you for Go Shiina <3  In general Zestiria is a 7/10, it's an enjoyable game with a decent story and characters but it has some pretty obvious gameplay issues and questionable design decisions.

It seemed to lack a lot of the twists and turns that typical Tales games are known for, not that it didn't have some moments, both of the serious and of the laugh-so-hard-the-optional-boss-destroys-you-while-you-wipe-your-tears-away variety. Side note: Some blood in cutscenes when people get stabbed would be nice, just what are you trying to teach these kids Bandai? The characters really do save the story from being abysmally cliche, or at least distract you from that fact. And to reiterate, it's not that the game didn't have some gut-wrenching all up in your 'feels' moments, you just saw them coming from like the 5th dungeon away.   Gameplay  The more action oriented Tales battle systems have never been a selling point to me, this one was no different. You will certainly swell with accomplishment as the pieces to this woman composed entirely of rubik's cubes slowly fall in to place. It felt like the tutorial didn't end for me until I was around 30 hours in, and I've played several other Tales games. Overall  ♥♥♥♥ yeah I'm recommending this. If for no other reason than that optional boss killed me a second time before I finally stopped laughing.
